My journey to Ingolstadt which had
been deferred by these events was now
again determined upon,
I obtained from my father a
respite of some weeks. This time
was spent sadly. My mothers death
and my speedy departure depressed
our spirits but Elizabeth endeavour
ed to renew the spirit of cheer
fullness in our little society. Since
the death of her aunt her mind
had acquired new firmness and
vigour. She determined to fulfil her
duties with the greatest exactitude
and she felt that the most imperious duty of
rendering her uncle and cousins hap
py.
had devolved
on her. She consoled me, amused her uncle,
instructed my brothers and I never
